item.title: When It Comes to Russia, Trump Navigates Conflicting Goals
item.description: President Trump’s efforts to court President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia are rife with contradictions about stability and displays of American power.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin in Alaska last August. Mr. Trump’s focus on strength has magnified tensions with Russia in regions like Latin America, where Mr. Putin has sought to extend his influence

item.title: Steny Hoyer, Longest-Serving House Democrat, to Retire From Congress
item.description: The Maryland congressman, who served as one of his party’s top leaders, plans to depart after nearly half a century in Congress, as his party looks toward generational change.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Steny Hoyer in October.

item.title: What We Know About the Fatal ICE Shooting in Minneapolis
item.description: Officials in Minnesota have disputed federal accounts of the shooting that killed a 37-year-old woman on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: A vigil last night in Minneapolis on the street where Renee Nicole Good was killed after an encounter with federal officers on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Withdraws the U.S. From More International Organizations
item.description: The executive order the president signed Wednesday follows a broader vision of American foreign policy that shuns coalition building and the consensus of nations.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking at the United Nations General Assembly last year. The U.N. did not immediately comment on the United States’ severing relationships with some of its organizations.

item.title: Spencer Pratt, Reality TV Star, Runs for Mayor of Los Angeles
item.description: The star of “The Hills,” whose house burned in the Palisades fire, has used his social media profile to hammer Mayor Karen Bass and other California Democrats over the past year.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
item.media:description: Spencer Pratt, whose home in Pacific Palisades was burned in last January's wildfire, announced his candidacy for mayor of Los Angeles on Wednesday.

item.title: Minnesota’s Dispute With Trump Administration Boils Over After ICE Shooting
item.description: The contradicting accounts of the ICE shooting in Minneapolis from the federal government and officials in Minnesota were the latest episode in a dispute that has been building for weeks.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images
item.media:description: Gov. Tim Walz at the State Capitol in St. Paul, Minn., on Monday.

item.title: Renee Good, Victim in Minneapolis ICE Shooting, Remembered for Her Kindness
item.description: Renee Good, 37, a resident of Minneapolis, was mourned on Wednesday as a cherished member of the community.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners placing flowers at a makeshift memorial near the site in Minneapolis where Renee Nicole Good, 37, was shot and killed in her vehicle.

item.title: Politicians Share Different Views of ICE Shooting Videos
item.description: In a polarized country, high-ranking officials were offering definitive, and starkly contrasting, accounts long before the facts could be established.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal officer shot and killed a 37-year-old woman in Minneapolis during an immigration enforcement operation Wednesday,

item.title: Trump Proposes Huge Increase in Military Spending
item.description: The president’s proposal for a $600 billion increase comes as his administration pushes for American imperialism.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military vehicles moving across the Arlington Memorial Bridge during a military parade in Washington in June.

item.title: University to Pay $500,000 to Professor It Fired Over Charlie Kirk Post
item.description: Austin Peay State University in Tennessee also reinstated Darren Michael, a tenured acting professor whose post about Mr. Kirk’s killing inflamed conservatives.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Austin Peay, based in Clarksville, Tenn., backtracked on firing the professor less than two weeks later, placing him on a paid suspension.

item.title: The ICE Shooting Came During an Operation Focused on Somali Immigrants
item.description: Federal immigration officials have stepped up enforcement activity in Minnesota amid a fraud scandal there that includes many people of Somali origin.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal officers surround Gregory Bovino, center, a senior Border Patrol official, at the site in Minneapolis where a federal immigration officer fatally shot a woman on Wednesday.

item.title: How Venezuela Is Already Rattling Republican Thomas Massie’s Primary Race
item.description: Most Republicans are on board with Trump’s aggression. Not Thomas Massie.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times; Jeff Faughender/Courier Journal, via Imagn
item.media:description: Representative Thomas Massie of Kentucky, left, is facing a Trump-backed challenge from Ed Gallrein, right.

item.title: Authorities Often Justify Motorist Shootings by Saying the Vehicle Was a Weapon
item.description: Federal officials said the Minneapolis driver who was shot by an immigration agent was using her vehicle as a weapon, a claim that local officials have disputed.
item.dc:creator: Shaila Dewan
item.media:credit: Tim Evans/Reuters
item.media:description: A driver was fatally shot by a federal agent in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: Beyond Minnesota, Social Media Fuels False Rumors of Fraud Among Somalis
item.description: The Ohio governor is once again trying to counter misinformation about immigrants, more than a year after baseless claims that Haitians in Springfield were eating pets.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Doral Chenoweth/Columbus Dispatch/USA Today Network, via Imagn Images
item.media:description: “We need to look at this as not a Somali problem, we need to look at this as a fraud problem,” Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio said during a news conference on Monday.

item.title: Deadly Minneapolis Encounter Is the 9th ICE Shooting Since September
item.description: All those targeted in the shootings were fired on while in their vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel, Albert Sun and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: The fatal shooting in Franklin Park, Ill., where a federal agent shot and killed a man during a traffic stop in September.

item.title: Horns, Whistles and Then Gunfire on a Minneapolis Street
item.description: A man opened his door to discover a tableau of deadly violence after a federal agent fatally shot a woman.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Tim Evans/Reuters
item.media:description: A man yelling at federal officers gathered near a vehicle after its driver was fatally shot in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: During Maduro Raid in Venezuela, a Close Call for Helicopters and Trump’s Plan
item.description: As a damaged U.S. helicopter struggled to stay aloft over Venezuela’s capital, the success of the entire operation hung in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Trump’s Claim to Venezuelan Oil Money Draws Scrutiny in Congress
item.description: Democrats say the president cannot take money from the proceeds of seized oil and control it himself, calling it a ‘slush fund’ that would fly in the face of the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Democratic Senators Chris Murphy of Connecticut, left, and Chris Van Hollen of Maryland criticized President Trump’s declaration that he will control the proceeds from oil produced in Venezuela.

item.title: Texas A&M Warns Professor Not to Teach Plato Because of Gender Rules
item.description: The university is reviewing courses under new rules restricting teaching about race and gender. Administrators told a philosophy professor to cut some lessons on Plato to comply.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Texas A&M University campus in College Station.

item.title: Lawmakers Split After Classified Briefings on Venezuela
item.description: Republicans praised what they characterized as a narrow and well-executed plan, while Democrats expressed alarm, warning that the mission was vaguely defined.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio speaking at the Capitol on Wednesday after a Senate briefing on operations in Venezuela.

item.title: Videos Show Federal Agent Shooting Motorist in Minneapolis
item.description: Clips analyzed by The Times show the moments immediately before and after a woman was fatally shot.
item.dc:creator: Devon Lum
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators embraced near the scene in Minneapolis where a federal immigration officer fatally shot a woman on Wednesday.

item.title: The shooting occurred less than a mile from where George Floyd was killed.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: George Floyd Square, on 38th Street East and Chicago Avenue, has been turned into a memorial site since his killing in 2020.

item.title: Rubio Lays Out Long-Term U.S. Involvement in Venezuela
item.description: The secretary of state told lawmakers the administration has a three-phase plan for Venezuela after ousting its leader, including seizing oil and controlling the proceeds.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio told reporters that the first priority would be “the stabilization of the country.”

item.title: Philip Yancey, Prominent Christian Author, Admits to Extramarital Affair
item.description: He said he would retire from writing and public speaking.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: St. Petersburg Times/Zuma Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Philip Yancey has been married to his wife, Janet, for 55 years.

item.title: Trump Deepens Scrutiny of Minnesota, a Potential Model for Other Blue States
item.description: The White House is intensifying and broadening its probes into fraud in states led by prominent Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents executed a search warrant as part of a fraud investigation in Bloomington, Minn., last month.

item.title: Trump officials threaten to expand a crackdown on fraud in Minnesota to other Democratic-run states.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Homan, President Trump’s border czar, speaking with Kristi Noem, the secretary of homeland security, outside the White House last year. Both have indicated that investigations into fraud in public would widen to include more states.

item.title: Local Officials Call for Federal Forces to Leave Minneapolis Following Fatal Shooting
item.description: Minneapolis leaders condemned the immigration crackdown, as federal officials defended the operation.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith and Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis during a news conference last year. Mr. Frey demanded Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents leave the city after they fatally shot a woman on Wednesday.

item.title: Justice Dept. Staff Fear Turmoil Diverts Them From Potential Threats
item.description: Rank-and-file prosecutors and agents have expressed serious concern that a hobbled work force hurts the government’s ability to identify and stop terrorist plots, cyberattacks, mass violence and fraud.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Across the Justice Department, rank-and-file workers have expressed deep concern that a denigrated, distracted and depleted work force undercuts the government’s ability to identify and stop terrorist plots, cyberattacks, mass violence and fraud, putting the country in a weaker position.

item.title: California Tech Executives Plot Against Rep. Ro Khanna Over Support of Wealth Tax
item.description: It’s hard right now to be a progressive Democrat in the heart of America’s tech industry.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Ro Khanna of California has publicly defended a proposed ballot measure for a wealth tax in California that has angered some of the state’s richest executives.

item.title: South Florida Is at Its Peak Political Influence After Maduro’s Capture
item.description: The region, which has long wielded influence on issues involving Latin America and the Caribbean, has now cemented a role as a global power player.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro’s capture prompted spontaneous celebrations in Doral, a city west of Miami that is full of Venezuelans on Saturday.

item.title: Federal Agent Shoots Woman Amid Minneapolis Immigration Crackdown
item.description: The person was killed, federal authorities said. Gov. Tim Walz asked for calm as protesters gathered.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith and Dan Simmons

item.title: After Maduro Ouster, Trump’s Venezuela Moves Pose a Challenge for GOP in Congress
item.description: Republicans have cheered the raid that ousted Nicolás Maduro but toiled to square their longstanding views with President Trump’s unclear and rapidly evolving strategy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We do not have U.S. armed forces in Venezuela, and we are not occupying that country,” Speaker Mike Johnson said on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Seizes Oil Tanker and Boards Another Amid Tensions With Russia
item.description: The first ship had eluded the Coast Guard after being stopped on its way to pick up oil in Venezuela. U.S. forces also boarded another tanker in international waters near the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: As Charlie Kirk’s Turning Point Pushes Into High Schools, Dissension Follows
item.description: Since Mr. Kirk’s death, chapters of his organization’s affiliate for teenagers have more than doubled in number, aided by politicians who have said they won’t tolerate opposition.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Lexi Parra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Club America members from Stratford High School in Houston found themselves caught between concerned parents on the left and Texas’ most powerful politicians on the right.

item.title: U.S. Appeals Court Won’t Take Up Case to Resurrect 9/11 Plea Deal
item.description: The decision removes a chance for the defendants to resolve the long-running case with the death penalty taken off the table. Instead, pretrial hearings are likely to resume.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit most likely means pretrial hearings in the case will resume before the 25th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

item.title: Los Angeles Begins to Recover After Devastating 2025 Fires
item.description: After wildfires destroyed much of Altadena and Pacific Palisades, Southern California is trying to heal, but also struggling with how to move forward.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Jill Cowan and Jesus Jiménez
item.category: Los Angeles Department of Water and Power
